articles.headline: Dearth of Candor From Japan’s Leadership
articles.snippet: Never has Japan’s weak, rudderless system of governing been so clearly exposed or mattered so much.
articles.abstract: Never has Japan’s weak, rudderless system of governing been so clearly exposed or mattered so much.
articles.lead_paragraph: This article is by   Hiroko Tabuchi,  Ken Belson and  Norimitsu Onishi.
articles.byline: By Hiroko Tabuchi, Ken Belson and Norimitsu Onishi

articles.headline: Not Forgotten
articles.snippet: When it comes to the Civil War and its depiction in museums, what seems to be evident up North is clouded and contested in the South, where conflicting sentiments linger.
articles.abstract: When it comes to the Civil War and its depiction in museums, what seems to be evident up North is clouded and contested in the South, where conflicting sentiments linger.

articles.headline: The Spirit of Sharing
articles.snippet: Social media technology has created new opportunities for museums to create interactivity inside and outside of their walls.
articles.abstract: Social media technology has created new opportunities for museums to create interactivity inside and outside of their walls.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHELLEY BERNSTEIN lives with her computer. Most days she hunkers down in her spartan office at the Brooklyn Museum where, as chief technology officer, she invents ways to keep people visiting the museum and its Web site, brooklynmuseum.org.

articles.headline: Hoping to Avoid the Knife
articles.snippet: Entrepreneurs haven’t yet struck gold in their search for an incision-free procedure to help millions of obese Americans, but it isn’t for lack of effort.
articles.abstract: Entrepreneurs haven’t yet struck gold in their search for an incision-free procedure to help millions of obese Americans, but it isn’t for lack of effort.
articles.lead_paragraph: In November, the prestigious Cleveland Clinic hailed a “scar-less” weight-loss surgery as one of the top 10 medical innovations expected this year.

articles.headline: A Clever End Run Around the Movie-Streaming Gremlins
articles.snippet: A new streaming company uses stacks of DVD players to send movies over the Internet, avoiding, for now, the restrictions of other services.
articles.abstract: A new streaming company uses stacks of DVD players to send movies over the Internet, avoiding, for now, the restrictions of other services.
articles.lead_paragraph: Fellow movie fans, we find ourselves in a time of great transition. We have one foot in the world of recorded movies — a time of fantastic selection, but also a time of tapes and discs. Our descendants will laugh their little holographic heads off when they hear about our ridiculous trips driving back and forth to the video store.

articles.headline: Dividends Will Enrich Bank Chiefs
articles.snippet: The Federal Reserve is expected to give some institutions permission to raise dividends, benefiting chief executives, who usually own large amounts of company stock.
articles.abstract: The Federal Reserve is expected to give some institutions permission to raise dividends, benefiting chief executives, who usually own large amounts of company stock.
articles.lead_paragraph: Even as ordinary investors look forward to the prospect of larger dividend payouts by the big banks, another group is poised for a rich payday: bank chief executives. In the next few days, the Federal Reserve is expected to give a handful of institutions, including JPMorgan Chase and Capital One, permission to pay higher dividends, another sign of the remarkable comeback of banks since the depths of the financial crisis.

articles.headline: Long Pause for Japanese Industry Raises Concerns About Supply Chain
articles.snippet: Many companies outside Japan remain uncertain, or decline to say, whether supplies of crucial components from Japan will hit air pockets.
articles.abstract: Many companies outside Japan remain uncertain, or decline to say, whether supplies of crucial components from Japan will hit air pockets.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Japan’s vaunted “just in time” approach to business has become “wait and see.”

articles.headline: Insurer to Forgo Rate Rise
articles.snippet: Blue Shield’s decision did not quiet discussion in California on giving the state the ability to simply block rate increases at health insurers.
articles.abstract: Blue Shield’s decision did not quiet discussion in California on giving the state the ability to simply block rate increases at health insurers.
articles.lead_paragraph: Blue Shield of California, a nonprofit insurer, on Wednesday withdrew its request to seek higher rates this year for individual policies amid stiff criticism from regulators and consumers.

articles.headline: The Times Announces Digital Subscription Plan
articles.snippet: Under the plan, which begins on March 28, visitors to NYTimes.com will be able to read 20 articles a month free. The most frequent users will pay $15 for a four-week subscription; print subscribers will have unlimited access.
articles.abstract: Under the plan, which begins on March 28, visitors to NYTimes.com will be able to read 20 articles a month free. The most frequent users will pay $15 for a four-week subscription; print subscribers will have unlimited access.
articles.lead_paragraph: The New York Times introduced a plan on Thursday to begin charging the most frequent users of its Web site $15 for a four-week subscription in a bet that readers will pay for news they are accustomed to getting free.
